list_definition.definition: rays of light, heat etc or of any radioactive substance

list_ex_of_english: Workers who contract diseases—including leukaemia—due to electromagnetic radiations—other than radiant heat—or to ionising particles are covered by disease number 25 in the schedule of diseases prescribed for industrial injuries purposes.
Secondly, the licensees will be absolutely liable for any injury or damage caused by ionising radiations emitted from anything on the licensed site.
The first point is ionising radiations.
Secondary radiation processes due to particle acceleration upon reflection will also be considered.
A number of specialist inspectors are already available to advise on problems relating to the use of ionising radiations.
A draft code of regulations covering the protection of workers in factories against ionising radiations is in preparaton.
High-power short-wave radiations are reported to induce lethal temperatures in animal life in stored materials, so that all stages are said to be destroyed with expedition and ease.
The ionising radiations regulations include a number of requirements to ensure the protection of staff, such as the requirements for measuring and regulating the doses they receive.
